item.title: Household and community studies of gender aspects of adaptation and impacts of climate change.
item.description: Household surveys and other participatory exercises conducted in communities adjacent to four on-station pairs of sites chosen to reflect similar rainfall regimes but different temperature regimes (climates analogous to those expected in the future as a result of estimated climate change). Between-pair, across-pair (within-country) and between-country comparisons will provide information on differences in attitudes and farming practices in relation to 'changes' in temperature. On-station trials (see Activity 3) will be used to sensitise farmers (and explore male/female differences) to potentially useful adaptations to climate change and obtain gender-specific feedback on farmers' assessments of the performance of those technologies.

item.title: Conduct an integrated assessment of climate sensitivity of agricultural systems and its effect on food security using AgMIP protocols in EA, Saf
item.description: In general there is scarcity of information on how projected changes in climate impact agricultural systems and how this translates into impacts on food security and income of poor farmers in the developing countries especially in sub-Saharan Africa. To date, much of the work on assessing impacts of climate change on agricultural systems is focused on large scale assessments which are mostly empirical. Site specific assessments which are essential in planning appropriate adaptation strategies are missing partly due to difficulties in getting reliable location specific downscaled projections of future climatic conditions and partly due to lack of data necessary to run process based system models such as DSSAT and APSIM. Also lacking is the integration of these impacts with prevailing socio-economic conditions in the regions to make realistic assessment on how changes in performance of agricultural systems due to changes in climate impact food security and income of the poor formers whose main livelihood is agriculture. This work is expected to fill this information conducting comprehensive assessment of climate change impacts on agriculture and assist planners in developing more appropriate adaptation strategies. "The Agricultural Model Inter-comparison and Improvement Project (AgMIP)” is a major international effort linking the climate, crop, and economic modeling communities with cutting-edge information technology to produce improved crop and economic models and the next generation of climate impact projections for the agricultural sector. ICRISAT is leading this effort in Eastern, Southern and western Africa regions by forming teams in selected countries form each of the three regions with support it received from UKaid through AgMIP. Another key aspect of this work is to enhance the capacities of national researchers in conducting these assessments by training them in the use of new tools and methods and by working with them in the application of these skills.

item.title: Conduct detailed ex-ante assessment of climate change impacts on target crops and assess adequacy of various soil, water, and crop management practices in alleviating the impacts of climate change
item.description: While increased temperatures are expected to reduce the duration of the crop, increase the demand for water due from increased evaporation and transpiration and lead to increased heat and water stresses, the combined effect of these impacts on crop growth and performance under different bio-physical conditions and under different management practices is unclear. Crop simulation models when properly calibrated and validated can provide valuable insights into these interactions and also help in identifying potential management practices that can be adapted to overcome negative impacts and capitalise on positive changes in the growing environments. ICRISAT in ESA is conducting a range of experiments at selected analogue climate location where average temperatures vary from 15-210C to quantify temperature effects on crop growth and performance and calibrate crop models. This activity builds on this work by applying these calibrated models to assess imapcts of future climates on crop growth and performance and conduct a detailed ex-ante assessment to identify management options with potential to overcome the negative impacts. Pigeonpea and groundnut are important complements to cereals in dryland farming systems and in human and livestock diets. Women often cultivate groundnut and pigeonpea for income (including high-value exports) and to improve the nutritional value of their family’s diet. Climate change poses a major challenge to these crops. Crop simulation models help to assess the impacts of climate variability and change on productivity of these crops and help in identifying better management options. Watersheds in the Indian SAT with different seasonal rainfall and soil types (Alfisols and Vertisols) are prioritized for conducting farmer-participatory experiments on groundnut and pigeonpea. Four promising varieties of pigeonpea and groundnut will be experimented for ex-ante assessment of climate change impacts on these crops.

item.title: Simulation of yield components for representative West African maize, millet, peanut, sorghum genotypes for wet, dry, current climates (using historical analogues; links to CRP1.1)
item.description: Continental West Africa offers the most striking, multi-decadal climate change clues on record, with historical evidence of rainfall decrease magnitudes comparable to those proposed under anthropogenic climate change (Traore et al., 2007; Haussmann et al., 2012). Yet, assessments of climate change impacts on food security generally prioritize long-term yield projections driven by GCM outputs subject to high uncertainty, limited downscalability, and simulated by crop models where regional agro-biodiversity, (a)biotic stress patterns, physiological traits of importance and management practices (inter alia) are poorly represented. Over the past 3 decades, ICRISAT and its partners have assembled a ca. 40,000 station-years dataset of ground rainfall records for West Africa, and contributed to the collation of various historical multi-environments trial datasets for maize, millet, peanut and sorghum, some of which have been documented in the agro-trials online database. Our hypotheses are: i/ that historical trial data from the region can support the calibration of 20 representative ecotypes in 3 crop models; ii/ that models can simulate yield probabilities consistent with published agricultural statistics from the region; iii/ that significant yield differences can be modeled for contrasted (dry, wet) climate baselines; iv/ that improved representation of regional agro-biodiversity, physiology, stresses and management reduces simulated yield differences compared to published climate change impact studies.

item.title: Evaluation / phenotyping of genetic diversity for adaptation to climate change (links to CRP3.5 & 3.6, CIMMYT, IRRI)
item.description: Climate change is often seen as dreadful waves of heat annihilating crops by their effect on grain set, and this has put a lot of emphasis on heat tolerance research. Increases in temperature also accelerate the accumulation of thermal time for the different phenophases. Model simulations predict major yield decrease in future climate in different crops (Cooper et al 2009), mostly because of shorter cropping cycles, but that could fairly easily be dealt with by breeding longer duration cultivars. Less focus has been put on the effects that slight changes in temperature can have on the plant-water relations. Under climate change conditions, but also under current climate variability, an increase in temperature increases the evaporative demand (Vadez et al., 2012) and by definition decreases the productivity of water (TE, Tanner and Sinclair 2003). Therefore, adapting to climate change or current climate variability is first an issue of maintaining high water productivity, especially where drought is an issue (Vadez et al., 2012). In the past few years, we have accumulated considerable evidence of intra-specific diversity for the capacity of stomata to partially close under vapor pressure deficit (VPD) above 2-2.5 kPa. The “midday stomatal closure” has been known for long (Black and Squire, 1979). Genotypic differences for that trait have been identified only recently in soybean (Fletcher et al., 2007), pearl millet (Kholova et al., 2010), chickpea (Zaman-Allah et al., 2011), cowpea (Belko et al., 2012), sorghum (Gholipoor et al., 2010). This trait has dramatic beneficial effects on the soybean yield across the US (Sinclair et al., 2010), especially so in the driest years. Our hypotheses are: (i) H1- that there is untapped genetic diversity in the reference collections; (ii) H2 – that differences in these responses lead to higher water productivity (TE); (iii) H3 – That this trait relates to plant hydraulics; (iv) H4 – that crop simulation modeling can tell us in what crop/region combination there can be a worthy-of-breeding yield increase due to this trait.

item.title: Identifying role of social institutions, social capital and social networks in adaptation processes & practices; mobilising & supporting building social capital; developing community based climate change preparedness plans (links to CRP2); establish links to EA & WA adaptation projects
item.description:
Climate change, one of the greatest development challenges of the present times, is already having discernible effects on communities (IPCC, 2007). Since Kyoto, the idea of climate change as not simply an environmental issue, but one of social justice, has been given increasing recognition. It is a well-known fact now that the impacts of climate change are felt severely by the poorest and marginalised people, particularly those in the semi-arid regions in developing nations. It is also well recognized that climate impacts will exacerbate existing inequalities as it would have serious implications for women because of greater responsibilities and less access to resources. Climate change is making it less likely that the Millennium Development Goals, including improving gender equality, will be met. Thus, climate change is exacerbating existing gender inequality, and will continue to do so unless addressed with gender-sensitive approaches . The inequitable distribution of rights, resources and power– as well as repressive cultural rules and norms – constrain the ability of many women to take action on climate change. However, poor and marginalised men often contend with similar constraints. It is in the face of such constraints that the poor and marginalised look for social networks that help them in coping with, if not entirely overcoming, the severe impacts of climate change. Alongside this, is the fact that men and women have different knowledge pertaining to livelihood practices in coping with climate change.
This proposal sets the framework for developing a better understanding of knowledge systems/strategies in terms of climate change, food security and gender by analyzing women’s roles, negotiation and bargaining success in their engagement in activities towards achieving food security in the face of climate change in risk-prone villages in the drylands of India. The study will focus on two aspects: social networks/collective actions; and livelihood practices.

item.title: Participatory testing of technologies for reduced risk (e.g. micro-dosing, seed priming), increased profitability and stability (e.g., soil and water conservation, forecast based decisions) and enhanced soil quality (e.g., CA, agroforestry)
item.description: In the semi-arid areas where agriculture is a risky enterprise, farmers adopt low input management practices to protect their investments from potential losses during unfavourable seasonal climatic conditions. While these practices are effective in reducing risk in poor seasons, they are not capable of increasing much needed productivity and income and capitalise on good seasons. A synthesis of earlier work at ICRISAT which led to development of “Hypothesis of Hope” highlighted that the potential gains in productivity that smallholder farmers can achieve by adopting available low risk management technologies compared to potential losses the low input smallholder farming community suffer from the productivity losses through changes in climate. Hence coping adequately with current climatic variability through development and promotion of low risk productivity enhancing technologies is considered as an important step in making communities resilient to challenges posed by current variability and future changes in climatic conditions. Some of the technologies that ICRISAT has developed in collaboration with partners from various national and international institutions include micro-dosing or targeted application of affordable doses of fertilizer, improved soil and water conservation practices to guard against the dry spells of varying duration, seed priming to enhance germination and help establish good crop stand especially under delayed on set of rainy season and locally relevant conservation agriculture practices such as basin planting. Despite their value and usefulness in enhancing productivity without increasing risk, their adoption is limited due to lack of awareness about these technologies and potential gains that can be harvested. This activity is aimed at addressing this issue through participatory evaluation focusing more on addressing the constraints to adoption by farming communities.

item.title: Testing and promotion of effective communication methods and formats for presenting climate information including seasonal climate forecasts tailored to the end user needs.
item.description: In a situation where several management decisions such which crops and varieties to grow on how much land and how much to invest on what inputs are to be made well before knowing how the season is going to be, seasonal climate forecasts are expected to provide a basis for farmers to make informed decisions. Seasonal climate forecasts are issued regularly by various national, regional and international organizations and are available for most parts of the world where rainfed agriculture is practiced by smallholder farmers. The reliability of these forecasts especially in Eastern and southern Africa were found to be good mainly due to the strong influence of ENSO phenomenon on rainfall and improved ability to predict the phenomenon. However, use of these forecasts by smallholder farmers is limited due to lack of awareness about the forecasts and non-availability of the forecast information in a format that users can easily understand and utilise. Past efforts by ICRISAT and other organizations in the region have highlighted the usefulness and potential of these forecasts in planning and managing farms. However, farmer’s ability to understand the probabilistic nature of the forecast information and uncertainties associated with the forecasts remained as a major constraint. This activity is aimed at addressing this issue by testing and validating different methods to communicate the forecast information as well as enhancing their understanding about the probabilistic nature of the information. In addition the activity will also test various approaches for scaling up this service with due consideration to the limited capacity of the extension services in these countries and increased availability and use information and communication technologies.

item.title: Household modeling tools tested and adapted for evaluating impacts of climate risk and risk management interventions on rural livelihood resilience in 2 countries; Models for crop and water management applied to climate risk and its management in 4 countries.
item.description: Since agriculture is one of the most weather dependent sectors, a good understanding of effects of climate variability on agricultural systems is an important first step in adapting agriculture to current variability and future changes in climate. However, the complex nature of agriculture involving many direct and indirect interactions between climate, soil, crop and management makes the task of assessing climate impacts on agriculture more difficult and challenging. This requires use of complex analytical tools such as crop simulation models whose calibration and validation requires special skills. This activity is planned to address this need by developing and implementing a training program that enhances the capacity of researchers in analyzing climate data and in assessing climate impacts on agriculture.

item.description: One of the key areas that the CCAFS regional office in Eastern Africa in consultation with partners from national agricultural research, meteorological and extension agencies has identified to make farmers more resilient to climate impacts is promoting use of climate information in farm level decision making. This is based on the results from the pilot studies which have clearly established the potential benefits from such interventions. The main constraints that these studies have identified are good information on location specific agro-climatological constraints and opportunities and on reliability of seasonal climate forecasts. This activity is planned to develop appropriate formats for developing and presenting climate information for agricultural decision making and to undertake a critical assessment of reliability of forecasts issued by the national met services.

item.description: During 2011-2012 ICRISAT and CCAFS theme 2 and CCAFS East Africa Regional office pilot tested the effectiveness of different methods of communicating downscaled seasonal climate forecast information to farmers in Wote division, Eastern Province, Kenya and evaluated its impact on management and productivity of smallholder farms. The findings of that study have clearly demonstrated that those farmers with improved understanding and access to climate information managed farms differently compared to farmers in control villages and invested more on crop management leading to increased productivity and higher returns on investment. This proposal seeks to extend this initial study for further testing and refining of the tools used and methodology followed, define and document the process of implementation of training workshops and communication of climate information and convert the process followed into an executable model program.

item.title: Assess land use change dynamics, deploy GHG measurement equipment at long-term dryland sites, including Jatropha plantations; assess biomass production potential from annual crops, perennial trees crops, and natural vegetation across an agro-ecological gradient (with ICRAF; links to CRP1.1).
item.description: A major source of carbon emissions is deforestation and forest degradation with 0.9– 2.2 Pg C / yr being released to the atmosphere (Houghton 2010). Clearing of land for agricultural practice is the primary driver of deforestation, particularly in tropical regions (Geist & Lambin 2002) with the Sudanian eco-zone of West Africa being the worst effected area in SSA (Brink & Eva 2009). Despite this dramatic expansion population growth continues to outstrip increases in food production, thus intensifying the land-use pressure (Mwangi 1996). African ecosystems contribute about 20% of global NPP and 20 percent of global CO2 emissions (0.3 ± 0.2 PgC / year) due to forest degradation and deforestation (Ciais et al. 2011). Despite the importance of African ecosystems to the global carbon budget, and the socio-economic vulnerability to a changing climate, there is still a lack of studies addressing these important issues. Semi-arid regions with extensive savanna woodland have been particularly neglected. Increasing agricultural yields has been proposed as a potential mechanism for reducing deforestation and resulting CO2 emissions (Angelsen 2010). Agricultural intensification is thought to have the potential to support the increasing food demands of a growing rural population. However many extensive land-use systems are marginal in productivity terms with often little adaptive capacity (Lambin et al. 2000). More than 40% of the population in Africa live in arid, semi-arid or dry sub-humid areas, increasing the vulnerability of the extensive savanna coverage in these regions (FAO 2007). Consequently, improving our spatially explicit understanding of the both the degradation of natural vegetation and complete conversion to agriculture will allow us to identify areas that are most vulnerable.

item.title: Analysis of long-term legume pest dynamics data from ICRISAT Patancheru in relation to agro-climatology. Mapping of climate variability and change in India, based on historic gridded climate data. Assessing changes in climates and water balances for selected contiguous SAT areas of India, under PRECIS projected high resolution temperature and rainfall situations.
item.description:
Climate change is one of the major challenges being faced by Agriculture in India, more so in the Semi-Arid Tropics (SAT) of the country. Analysis of long-term trends in temperature based on 47 stations in India has indicated that overall, 55 to 80% of the stations showed increasing trends in average annual temperature A few studies indicate significant negative and positive trends in annual rainfall at different parts of India. Great variability in climate exists in different parts of India and there are some regions that show climate change. Length of the growing period (LGP) is likely to change due to increased crop water requirements and rainfall aberrations. Storage of both surface water and groundwater is becoming increasingly important as climate change is affecting the demand and supply gap. Anticipated climate change is likely to affect dynamics and interaction among species and could change the pattern of pest damage and pest control strategies.
There is a need to assess the climate variability and change occurring and to review the areas falling under different climate zones in India to understand the changing rainfall and temperature patterns in the last few decades. Daily gridded temperature and rainfall data sets for Indian region with one degree resolution were developed by the IMD using temperature data of 395 quality controlled stations and rainfall data of 1803 stations and this data will be used. Computer programs are to be developed to compute weekly ET and climatic water balance for 34 years (1971-2004) for assessing changes in water balance and LGP. Climates for each year to be classified in to six types based on the annual moisture index, and as per the classification of Thornthwaite and Mather. Pixel-wise changes in climates are to be quantified using ArcGIS software.

item.title: Evaluation of promising crop technologies/traits/management practices for productivity enhancement of pearl millet and chickpea under current and future climates using virtual crop model in target regions and countries.
item.description: The climate change in terms of higher temperatures, changing patterns of precipitation and water availability and increased frequency of extreme weather events such as floods, storms and droughts will affect crop productivity. Depending upon the location on the globe, crop yields will be either negatively or positively affected by climate change. However, in the arid and semi-arid tropical (SAT) regions the effect of climate change is predicted to be mostly negative, thus threatening food security in these regions where large number of hungry people live and mostly depend on agriculture for their livelihood. The dryland cereal like pearl millet is an important stable food crop which provide maximum calorie in western and central African countries and arid and semi-arid climate states of India and also provide feed and fodder for the livestock. The chickpea is an important grain legume crop which provides protein in the vegetarian diet of the poor people in Asian and east and southern African countries. The crop improvement program at ICRISAT is developing yield enhancing abiotic and biotic stress resistant technologies for the target regions to face the changing climate and market preferences. But the performance of the promising technologies under different farm management practices and changing climate is not adequately assessed which will provide evidence based information to guide the breeding strategies. In this activity we will use process based dynamic crop model suite to calibrate the current popular cultivars and the ‘virtual’ cultivars will be created that have the traits that breeders are targeting, such as traits for increased yield, drought tolerance, and heat tolerance. These virtual cultivars will be simulated for current and future climate change condition and the changes (increase) in yields will be compared to yields simulated with current ‘baseline’ cultivars and management practices of pearl millet and chickpea. The location specific calibrated virtual cultivar genetic coefficients will be used to simulate the yields and climate change impacts spatially for every 10 square kilometer pixel on the land surface of the earth using the spatial crop modeling suite in collaboration with IFPRI and Harvest Choice challenge program. The result will help to identify the homogenous zones for targeting technology development and diffusion.

item.title: Assess the impact of changing socio-economic conditions and climates on production of dryland crops, prices, food availbility and nutritional security in the semi-arid regions of Africa and Asia using integrated modeling approach (linked with CRP2, AgMIP, ILRI).
item.description: In face of increasing variablity of socio-economic conditions (liberalizationof trade and markets, urbanization, population and income growth etc.) and biophysical environment (e.g. climate change, land degradation, water scarcity, etc.), dryland crops (Sorghum, millets, groundnut, chickpea and pigeon pea) have remained an important mainstay of food economies in the semi-arid tropical countires of Africa, Asia and Latin America. the relative hardiness of staple dryland cereals and legumes has made it possible to provide livelihood opportunities for growing popualtions under harsh and incrasingly mariginal environment under changing climate. These crop play an important part in maintaining availability of food and feed resources that help diversify prodcution into livestock and create opportunities for risk environment and income growth. Despite this curcial role, much less is know about the potential impacts of cliamte change and globalization on future of dryland crop especially on production, prices, food availability and nutritional security in the semi-arid regions of Africa and Asia. This activity will answer the question like what are the alternative futures and outlooks for dryland cereals and grain legumes under changing climate and socio-economic scenarios? The global integrated model framework of IMPACT is used to examine such issues and look at the possible adaptation strategies the developing countries might undertake to cope the changing climate scenarios. This model will also integrate the high resolution climate change impact results from spatial crop model of dryland crops in to economic model to assess the impact of climate on production, prices and food security level in the semi-arid regions of Asia and Africa.

item.title: Transformational adaptation and international development: What are the risks, costs, benefits and barriers.
item.description: Climate adaptation can occur in different ways and to different extents with one framing of this being incremental, systemic and transformative adaptationwith the increasing extent of climate changes. The CSIRO Climate Adaptation Flagship established a project four years ago to seek to understand transformational climate adaptation processes in Australian agriculture. Sarah Park (currently WorldFish) previously led this project. This project has developed both some theoretical framing as well as empirical analysis. Some of this has already been published or is in the process of being published with more to come. This is currently the most substantial body of work globally on this topic. The results have received considerable attention by industry and policy (nationally and internationally) as well as contributing to what seems to be an area of research that is now attracting considerable interest. This project aims to draw upon existing research from CSIRO and the research program Climate Change, Agriculture and Food Security (CCAFS) in order to bring together our joint current thinking and framing of transformational adaptation in the context of international development.

item.title: Climate risk analogue mapping for germplasm conservation and evaluation
item.description: Most of the studies being undertaken relating to climate change adaptation focus on agronomic impacts of climate change. However, no systematic efforts have been made to evaluate genebank collections by plant breeders and researchers to facilitate adaptation and reduce the impacts of changing climates on food and nutrition security and farmers’ livelihoods. This project employs climate analogue tool to identify hotspots for germplasm collection and evaluates a range of germplasm and varieities for their performance in climate stress environment in farmers fields.

item.title: Managing climate related risks to improve livelihood resilience and adaptive capacity in agricultural ecosystems in Southern Mozambique.
item.description: Within the Government of Mozambique there is a strong interest in, and a growing commitment to climate change issues. At the national level, the government is leading efforts to raise the topic of climate change on the development agenda. Mozambique is particularly vulnerable to climate change due to its geographic location at the confluence of many international rivers flowing into the Indian Ocean; its land area that is below sea level; high vulnerability to cyclones and storms; high temperatures; aridity; infertile soils; lack of communications infrastructure; a high level of illiteracy; high population growth rate; absolute poverty and a high dependence on natural resources that require predictable rain. In the next twenty years Mozambique is predicted to lose 25 per cent of its agricultural productive capacity. These changes will negatively affect crop yields resulting in price increases for basic staples, which can have a serious effect on health and increasing child malnutrition. Systems need to be put into place to manage the risks from such weather and climate variability. The ability to smooth gains and losses due to climate variability requires improved climate information and an institutional framework in which the public and private sector can act quickly and efficiently when provided reliable information.

item.title: Mapping risks and opportunities for targeting appropriate crop and livestock adaptation strategies in East Africa
item.description: The activity builds on the outcomes of the regional science workshop in June 2012 and activities initiated in 2012. In 2013, the focus will be on-farm evaluation of promising technologies for enhancing adaptive capacity, integrated with risk management and mitigation strategies across the CCAFS sites in East Africa. Specific activities include sustainable land management, agro-forestry, participatory selection of multiple stress tolerant cereal and legume varieties, root crops, tissue culture bananas and horticultural crop in Kenya and Tanzania. In Uganda, the focus is on evaluation and promotion of promising bean based technologies for enhancing farmer capacity to adapt building on Pan African Bean Research Alliance (PABRA).

item.title: Regional capacity building on using Climate Scenarios and Analogues for designing adaptation strategies in agriculture
item.description: In 2012, the activity focused on building regional capacity on climate modeling techniques and tools and use of climate scenarios and analogues to strengthen national adaptation policies and plans. As a follow up to the capacity building initiatives in 2012, one farmer exchange visit will be organized among analogue sites in the region in collaboration with the national partners to enhance adaptation learning. The farmer exchange visits will be documented through video testimonials. A follow-up study to the pilot of the FoTF in Tanzania in 2012 will be undertaken in 2013 to explore the effectiveness of farmer-to-farmer exchange visits for enhancing adaptation learning, identify potential adaptation and diversification pathways, and explore the social and cultural factors that enhance or hinder adaptation.

item.title: Capacity building workshops on the analogue method, cataloguing climatic risk management strategies, understanding social and cultural barriers to adapting through farmer exchange visits between analogue sites.
item.description: Scientific evidence gathered in the last couple of decades suggests that climate conditions are changing rapidly and that this trend will likely continue and even accelerate. These anticipated changes in climate baseline, variability and extremes will have far-reaching consequences on agricultural production, posing additional challenges to meeting food security for a growing world population. As climate emigrates between regions, it will disproportionally affect resource-poor and marginalized farmers who have lower adaptive capacities but may depend entirely on agriculture for their livelihoods. Therefore, male and female farmers alike need to enhance their adaptive capacities. Achieving adapted farming systems for changing climate conditions in space and time will require the development of new technologies and testing across a range of pilot sites, as well as modeling activities to outscale the potential of individual adaptation options across a wide range of geographies. The CCAFS Farms of the Future project will use the climate analogue tool to connect farmers to their possible climate futures via farm visits. This project will address the following working hypothesis: by identifying and connecting analogue sites, research can: 1) enable farmers to better envision how their site-specific agricultural future might look, and 2) permit targeted on-the-ground testing of cropping systems/technologies climate resilience. In sum, we are hoping to learn the potential of the climate analogues tool/methodology to improve farmers adaptive capacities and preparedness for eventual transformational adaptation.

item.title: A methodological development of an online tool for the identification of Target Population Environments: improving the predictions of agricultural production using crop models
item.description: The expected increases in temperature and shifts in precipitation regimes are predicted to cause significant changes in crop productivity across the globe, through direct abiotic influence or through associated changes in pest and disease pressure. While significant adaptive capacity exists within agricultural and socio-economic systems, models suggest that the germplasm that currently underpins production is likely to be out-reached in some places by change. Hence, crop improvement through conventional breeding or through biotechnological innovations is hailed as a crucial strategy to ensure long-term maintenance or gain in agricultural productivity. Given the long lead-time between commencement of a breeding program and the release and large-scale adoption of new cultivars in farmers' fields, it is critical that breeding programs are initiated today to address future problems. It is therefore key that priorities are developed for crop improvement programs based on sound ex-ante analysis of future benefits, and that coherent strategies across multiple countries and between institutions are adopted and implemented. International and national donor and government policies should be coordinated in enabling the conception and implementation of these strategies.

item.title: The influence of climate change on the occurrence of crop pests and diseases
item.description:
Climate-related variability in agricultural production affects billions of lives worldwide. Models exist that simulate the response of crops to climate variability and change by using direct climate model output (i.e. at the regional scale, ~100km). Climate is known to be a strong determinant of the yield of a number of crops, both directly and through intermediate drivers such as irrigation water availability and incidence of pests or diseases. Many of the processes associated with these intermediate drivers are understood. However, despite continued calls by the IPCC, climate models have not yet been used to assess the predictability implicit in these relationships.
This project combines established capacity in crop-climate modelling (see figure) with a recently-developed set of tools that simulate the occurrence of crop disease and/or pests. The project will be amongst the first to develop and evaluate process-based modelling suites that assess both the direct and intermediate drivers of regional-scale crop yield, whilst taking full account of associated uncertainty. The project will also examine the efficacy of climate analogue techniques in translating regional-scale climate predictions into farmer-relevant information on likely future biotic and abiotic stresses. The understanding and modelling capability gained during the project will underpin assessments of the adaptive capacity of cropping systems to climate variability and change. By focussing on the seasonal-to-multi-decadal timescales, the project will ensure relevance to adaptation efforts and policy.
The project will use and modify the GLAM crop model (figure 1), which was designed for use with large-scale gridded meteorological data, such as that produced by weather and climate models. GLAM has been used with climate model output for a range of crops in tropical and extra-tropical environments. A number of pest and disease models are available, for example the potato moth model of CIP, the CGIAR centre that leads on potato research. Once an integrated forecast system has been developed, it will be used to assess the efficacy of adaptation options.

When communicating with farmers, policy makers, or other stakeholders, the evidence provided needs to be grounded in science, and the uncertainties associated with climate related risks should be clarified. Dissemination to the farmers has been weak due to poor communication between scientists and farmers, use of language and format that is not easily understood by farmers and delays in relaying the information. This project seeks to increase farmers’ understanding of climate-induced risks affecting agriculture. It will explore a variety of interventions to increase agricultural production and enhance resilience to climate variations. Social learning and innovation amongst farmers can be enhanced by promoting farmer-to-farmer interactions and interactions between farmer organizations and public and private institutions that would add value to the farm enterprises of interest by providing knowledge, information, technologies or other relevant services. In order to manage climate risks and to adapt to climate change, this project aims to build new and effective partnerships between Maseno University, local farmer organizations, the ministry of agriculture extension services, NGOs involved in agricultural advisory services, the Kenya meteorological service, the Kenya agricultural research institute, local agro-dealers and the media.

item.description: Discussions of pro-poor mitigation options are limited by the lack of reliable data at spatial scales relevant to decision making. This activy establishes a multidisciplinary workgroup consisting of CGIAR and external experts tasked with developing a standard protocol for data collection, analysis, and interpretation of the greenhouse gas balance and livelihood indicators for smallholder systems at the whole-farm and landscapes scales. The significance of including multiple spatial scales and involving economic, social and ecological parameters cannot be understated. Many agricultural management practices have interacting—sometimes complimentary and sometimes antagonistic—impacts on greenhouse gas emissions and livelihoods. Thus, understanding cumulative impacts requires consideration of the various sources and sinks. Furthermore, aggregating biophysical effects to spatial scales larger than the field aligns them with decisions makers’ influence; whole-farms with households and landscapes with communities and governments

item.title: Quantification of GHG emissions to inform mitigation interventions in East African agricultural systems
item.description: In the East Africa region there is no comprehensive baseline data for greenhouse gases (GHG) emissions from agricultural systems. Major farming systems have not been systematically characterized for GHG emissions, with few isolated initiative gathering data for some farming activities. The main reasons for data scarcity are lack of analytical facilities and human capacity to conduct measurements complying with international standards. The lack of data on emissions for agricultural systems has led to poor evaluations of mitigation options, mostly based on emission factors from the developed world and biogeochemical models calibrated elsewhere. Because most sub-Saharan African countries have agricultural dependent economies (estimates above 30% GDP), development plans must consider the environmental impact of different intensification pathways – in terms of GHG emissions but also with regard to water supply and water quality or biodiversity - that are designed to achieve food security in the region. The proposed work aims at bringing the expertise needed to address the knowledge gap in measurements and quantification of GHG emissions, with a partnership between international, national institutes and local universities to guarantee relevance and sustainability of the achieved outcomes. The project will contribute to the development of field and laboratory protocols to be tested in selected sites, while building the capacity of researchers in the region to measure GHG fluxes as well as system productivities. Field case studies will aim to evaluate mitigation options in terms of emissions per unit crop product, crop productivity and profitability, and social acceptability (e.g labor productivity, tastes and preferences). Baseline data generated by the project will be availed to support regional and national policy initiatives such as the National Climate Change Response Strategy (NCCRS) and finally, to calibrate and validate process- biogeochemical models such as the DNDC model allowing to trace the fate of nutrients, to simulate crop production and to quantify greenhouse gas emissions.

In order to achieve this, a quick but reliable and inexpensive methodology is needed for estimating GHG fluxes. Little information is available on baseline emissions from different cropping regime in South Asia. This study attempts to test, validate and simulate GHG emissions using DNDC at the core CCAFS sites in South Asia and then simulate for the region.

A diversity of measurement and monitoring systems are needed to assess the efficacy of GHG-mitigation strategies; to understand the impact of emissions on the climate and the planet; to support carbon management strategies; and to guide future efforts in all of these areas. They use various strategies to know which traditional seed varieties will withstand increased salinity or grow in water stress areas and which native trees should be protected for food and fodder. This type of knowledge is critical for developing efficient adaptation measures. Women leaders have the advantage of accessing government programmes, schemes and resources to help poor farmers adapt. item.title: Building capacity for evidence-informed policies in East Africa through the Regional Learning Partnership (RLP
item.description: The RLP is a network of institutions from Eastern and Southern Africa with a common interest in the effects of climate change on agriculture and food security in the region. The partnership currently constitutes of 16 institutions spread across research, policy, advocacy and grassroots organizations. The RLP is structured under the strategic leadership of CCAFS with key input from all partners. Regional Learning Partnership (RLP) aims to build capacity for evidence-informed policy making across East Africa by mainstreaming research knowledge into national policies, development plans and targeted local action. It is a learning platform that endeavours to identify the gaps in knowledge and information, and the best way of disseminating information. The RLP works across scales, from national, regional to international levels and provides a platform for identifying policy driven research. Through shared learning, the partnership is promoting enhanced up-scaling and co-generation of knowledge and tools. Through the RLP, the regional program supports dialogue with national, regional and international policy makers and actors with regard to inclusion of agricultural issues in climate change policies, and of climate issues in agricultural policies, including international climate change negotiations within the UNFCCC framework. This will include developing new partnerships and strengthening existing partnerships through active participation in regional and national stakeholder forums, including other Africa-wide initiatives. To contribute to international climate change policy discussions, the regional program in collaboration with ACPC and COMESA will continue to support the African Group of Negotiators (AGN) through a team of scientists and policy makers to prepare a Technical paper and Position paper on Agriculture and Climate Change. The papers will provide the scientific evidence required to demonstrate a compelling case for investing in agricultural research and technologies for upscaling climate smart agriculture in Africa. Stakeholder workshops will be held to strengthen the regions voice in seeking to integrate agriculture in the ongoing UNFCCC process. To inform national level policy, the regional program is supporting the NAP process in Kenya. In 2012, the regional program supported the development of the Kenya National Climate Change Policy (KCCAP) 2013 – 2017, which was launched in early 2013. In order to take forward the implementation of the Priority Adaptation and Mitigation Actions for Agriculture identified in the KCCAP, the regional program will collaborate with the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources (MEWNR) and the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries (MALF) to organise a series of stakeholder consultations which will culminate in a National Adaptation for Agriculture Event. At the same time, the regional program will work with partners to enhance CCAFS visibility in the region by organizing and also participating important events such as conferences and exhibitions like AMCEN and CCDA 3.

item.title: MarkSim version 2 and associated tools, development and testing; and revision of MarkSim-GCM with CMIP5 data
item.description: MarkSim® is a third-order markov rainfall generator, first released in 2002, that is able to simulate the observed variance of rainfall in both tropical and temperate regions. It works from a large set of parameters based (in version 1's case) on a calibration dataset of some 10,000 stations worldwide that have in most cases more than 15 years of daily historical rainfall data. Climates were clustered into some 700 types, and some of the parameters of the MarkSim model calculated by regression from the cluster most representative of the climate point to be simulated. Since its release, the tool has been widely used in the agricultural modelling community, and it is now also being used in empirically downscaling the outputs from climate models to produce daily weather data that are characteristic of future climatologies that can then be fed to agricultural models to evaluate possible impacts in the future. Since 2002, another 30,000 stations of historical daily rainfall have been collected, and version 2 of MarkSim will make use of this greatly expanded calibration data set. See previous activity description for more detail on previous phases.

item.title: Soil profile characteristics database refinement, for use in agricultural impact modeling work.
item.description: Computer simulation models are now being widely used for impact assessment studies and for supporting policy decisions at different temporal and spatial scales. However, for application of these models detailed data bases are required that cover large regional areas. Unfortunately, this information is rarely available. The International Soil Reference and Information Centre (ISRIC) has developed a series of detailed soil databases, early versions of which have been converted for use in agricultural impact model applications. Accurate soil data that represent local soil conditions are important for the simulation of the soil water and nitrogen balances, especially for rainfed conditions where water is limiting. Soil data can be extremely variable across space, and scaling up from point-based simulations to grid-based simulation provides considerable challenges related to input data. There is now a WISE Version 3.1 database, and converting this into model format would allow many more additional soil profiles to be utilized, that may be more representative of the local conditions.

item.title: Validation of hybrid global cropland extent data layers.
item.description: Reliable global data sets of cropland extent would seem to be a key resource for many different purposes. For example, the future agricultural potential of tropical areas will play a critical role in meeting the challenge of future food security. While crop yield can be estimated with some reliability using a limited sample of ground observations, reliable crop acreages and their spatial distribution are rarely available. Different remote sensing products are available, but comparison work (see, for example, Fritz et al. (2010), â€œComparison of global and regional land cover maps with statistical information for the agricultural domain in Africaâ€, International Journal of Remote Sensing 31 (9), 2237-2256), indicates that some products do better in some places and some in others. The work here seeks to produce a hybrid product that combines the best of the available information.

item.title: Impact model wiki population and testing (AgriMod.org).
item.description: The aim is to develop a web resource that will serve as a central hub for information on agricultural modelling activities (primarily encompassing biophysical models of agricultural processes). It will streamline the process of accessing resources and sources of information and data for modelling and research purposes. The aim is to create a site that will facilitate greater levels of co-operation between modelling groups, data providers, funding organisations and stakeholder beneficiaries, in order to increase modelling research capacity to support food security and climate change initiatives. The purpose of the web site will be to serve the global research community by providing a resource, information and discussion centre that facilitates more and better quality research by the agricultural modelling and wider environmental and socio-economic research communities. It will also serve as a centre for contact between the scientific research community and policy development stakeholders at regional, national and international levels. The rationale for developing this web resource is the recognition of the need to facilitate greater up-take of modelling activities, particularly in developing countries, to support national capabilities to research food security and climate change impacts, mitigation and adaptation. There is further need to streamline the process by which new model activities are developed, and by which existing initiatives can be improved, to better support actions on improving food security and tackling climate change.

item.title: Collating and documenting regional databases for soils, historical climate, future climate scenarios, agricultural systems, and natural resources to analyze likely effects of specific adaptation and mitigation options of households.
item.description: Climate information is used in agriculture and food security on a range of timescales, from days (weather), months (seasonal outlooks) to decades (climate change scenarios) (Hellmuth et al. 2011). Providing information on climate between seasonal and decadal timescales has proved difficult, falling into the period where traditional forecast skill dies away and the climate change signal is difficult to detect against natural variability. Yet much policy, planning and investment decision-making falls into this time horizon (Stafford-Smith et al. 2011). Both the seasonal forecasting community and the climate change scenario community have developed techniques and methods for provision and communication of climate infomation, as well as the use of climate information in impacts assessment, planning, risk mitigation, adaptation, etc. Decision-making on 1-10 year timescales may require a hybrid approach that draws on btoh traditions. Yet there has been little research on the climate information needs on these timescales, on methods that can provide the required information, or on how to use what will necessarily be uncertain information in planning and decision making.

item.title: G-Range (global rangeland model) implementation.
item.description: Temperate and tropical rangelands occur throughout the world and support the livelihoods of millions of livestock-owning households. Global change, such as climate change associated with a build-up of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gasses, is anticipated to alter the services that rangelands provide. One means of increasing the likelihood that households, enterprises, and land managers will be able to adapt to future changes is if future conditions can be anticipated. A method of anticipating future conditions is through using simulations, where inputs into the simulations are modified as predicted in change scenarios. A means of simulating future changes in rangelands across the globe is sought. While numerous grassland and rangeland simulation models have been developed, none is amenable to use directly in global simulations. The work here seeks to develop a process-based simulation model that is spatially explicit and of moderate complexity. The model will allow global analyses of native rangelands and the changes they may undergo.

item.title: Quantification of regional scenarios using global integrated models.
item.description: The development and use of scenarios functions as a platform for the exchange and application of knowledge and experience between CCAFS researchers and policy makers, privator sectors, NGOs and other societal actors. Because scenarios allow for the capturing of uncertainties and systems complexity in a coherent and plausible yet surprising and challenging fashion, scenarios are also a tool for generating shared engagement. The next step in the scenarios process is to explore the implications of these qualitative scenarios through quantigication using GEC and economic models that focus on food security assessment. The quantification of the scenarios will increase their credibility and plausibility and their usefulness as contexts for the testing of policies and strategies. Initially, the scenarios quantification will be done through the close collaboration of two modeling teams--a team working with the IMPACT model developed at IFPRI and a team working with the GLOBIOM model developed at IIASA.

item.title: Case study in at least one CCAFS site on developing approaches to support smallholder decision making, linking with met services and household modelling.
item.description: Farmers in Sub-Sahara Africa, operating in risky and unpredictable environments, have to make decisions with very limited information available to them. Research on farmersâ€™ perceptions of climate change and variability indicate that in many communities there are perceptions, particularly regarding amounts and timing of rainfall, that are i) not generally reflected in analysed climatic data and ii) contradictory. Consequently farmers may be making decisions and implementing both short term management practices and longer term strategies that are inappropriate. Analysed historical data (from daily records made over several decades) is increasingly being made available in several countries (through work undertaken by UoR with partner institutions). At the same time a range of participatory approaches (including participatory farm management methods [Dorward et al 2003]) exist that could be adapted and used to communicate with farmers about analysed climate information in ways that enable farmers to make more informed (and therefore improved) short and longer term livelihood, farm and crop decisions. Key to this is understanding what information farmers want and need, being able to provide it in ways that are easy to understand and at the same time enable facilitate meaningful consideration of implications. Forecasts (long, medium and short) can provide further information of value to planning and decision making. Attempts to introduce these to farmers have had mixed success. With the improved understanding from the above there is scope to add some of these to the information that farmers receive in a more integrated and useful way. Preliminary fieldwork in Zimbabwe (June/July 2012) confirmed the need for and potential of research on this topic. Smallholders, working with extension staff successfully used a range of approaches in the initial steps 1-4 (steps summarised later in this document). Work is required to test the full approach at a range of locations with different characteristics (climate, agriculture, socioeconomic), draw lessons and facilitate wider implementation and scaling up. Capacity building amongst service providers, particularly extension services and NGOs that work directly with smallholders forms a necessary and important part of the project.

item.title: Refining and implementing CCAFS strategy on social learning and climate change decision support at the local level.
item.description: Phase 1: While a large body of literature is concerned with climate change communications and social learning in the developed world, less is available or applicable to the developing world. The differences between climate change communications approaches and social learning approaches should be articulated. Various approaches and tools are being developed and applied by the development community and the aim is to review the existing approaches, tools and decision aids that are applicable in this context, as well as the major stakeholders involved in the CCAFS target regions. The abilities of different communication tools to bring out stakeholdersâ€™ engagement in the exchange of perspectives on CCAFS issues should be a central consideration. Phase 2: In late 2011, CCAFS â€˜Theme 4â€™ issued a call for proposals for people and organizations to help develop a CCAFS â€˜strategy on communication and social learningâ€™. IDS/IIED were selected for the review and contributed to the subsequent process of designing and facilitating a May 2012 workshop in Addis Ababa. Drawing on the IDS/IIED review of current climate change communications and social learning approaches, tools and decision aids, as well as the Addis Workshop, we want to identify the main strengths and weaknesses in targeting specific stakeholders, as well as the gaps that will inform a CCAFS strategy to engage in this area. We are interested in different kinds of communication approaches, tools and decision aids for different levels of stakeholders (such as farmers, community groups, local governments, etc.). IIED and IDS will collaborate on this project and work closely with CCAFS, ILRI-KMIS and the mechanisms of engagement that are being established.

item.title: Use of the toolkit to influence and monitor behavioral changes of individuals, women and men groups or communities, organizations and institutions at subnational levels.
item.description: Climate variability and change is a major threat to livelihoods and food security of smallholder farmers. Over decades, farmers have developed adaptation strategies (technological) to cope with and adapt to climate variability and change. In 2011 and 2012 CCAFS in partnership with IUCN tested a toolkit (ToP-MECCA) to support and improve adaptation planning, monitoring and evaluation capacities of scientists in Burkina Faso, Niger, Ghana and Mali for the implementation of the participatory action research initiatives. The implementation of this toolkit by scientists in the four countries has allowed to (i) explore and successfully apply approaches and methods that enhance knowledge to action linkages with a wide range of partners at local, district and national levels and (ii) assemble data and tools for analysis and planning, monitoring and evaluation. The objective of this project is to enable scientists, grant makers, and managers to identify, formulate, verify, and make sense of behavioral changes of their interventions on climate change, agriculture and food security.

item.title: A maize and wheat germplasm/weather data curation system developed and implemented.
item.description: Every year CIMMYT sends promising lines coming out of the breeding pipelines of the global wheat and maize programs to a large number of partners in NARS located globally for wheat and in Africa, Asia and Latin America for maize, each location representing mega environments defined for both crops. The mega environments are utilized by the breeders to plan and target their breeding efforts. Many institutions evaluating these lines send feedback on yields, phenotypic information and pest and disease scorings. This data set, spanning several decades, can be utilized to analyze the impact of climate variability on yield in a large variety of environments. It can be used to calibrate crop models like DSSAT or APSIM over a long period for many different locations worldwide. Information on pests and diseases can be utilized to generate risk maps based on related climate data extracted for the individual locations. For all these purposes, the precision of the locations of the nursery sites has to be as high as possible. A large number of the sites were georeferenced when GPS was not available and thus often inaccurate. This emphasizes the need of the first step in correcting the inaccuracies with current tools and GPS information from nursery site managers. Based on this, creating the analogue layers will enable determination of the areas the nursery sites represent under current climate conditions. Utilizing climate change data sets will allow the identification of those areas that are predicted to have the climate conditions today other maize and wheat growing areas will experience in the future and to identify those areas that are under climate conditions currently that the nursery sites will experience in the future. This will allow the breeders to test new breeding material in such environments and to plan for shifts of climate and mega environments.

item.title: Suitable international maize trial data identified, collated and relevant climate / environment data of these trials reconstructed or accessed and analysis initiated.
item.description: This work aims to result in the targeted dissemination of adapted maize varieties with tolerance to heat stress and/ drought stress and farmer-preferred traits in hotspots of climate vulnerability. Climate predictions for EA and IGP show temperatures are likely to increase however very little research has been conducted in maize for tolerance to heat stress and combined heat and drought stress. There is currently limited phenotyping capacity for both heat stresss and combined heat and drought stress in EA and IGP. Repeatable screening protocols for drought stress can be achieved by screening in the dry season however screening for heat and combined heat and drought stress is much harder to manage resulting in loss of trials if a suitable stress level was not reached and large genotype x year variability. Climate change is also likely to change the prevelance, diversity and responsiveness of maize pests and diseases, thus further work is required on screening for biotic stress.

item.title: Effective gender-equitable climate change adaptation strategies for rural poor small-scale maize households in East Africa.
item.description: This work aims to provide policy recommendations for effective gender-equitable climate change adaptation strategies for rural poor small-scale maize households in East Africa. Climate change is threatening the livelihood and food security of many poor farmers in the African continent. The vulnerability of women (both in female- and male-headed households) and men to impacts of climate change are uneven and will be affected differently. Gender-disaggregated data will help us identify and understand the coping and adaptation strategies for climate change used by female and male farmers which in turn will inform gender-sensitive recommendations for coping and adaption strategies to climate variability and extreme events.

item.title: Analysis and modeling of wheat trial data to identify climate ready traits/ideotypes, and analogue sites in climate vulnerable regions with the medium-term objective of developing phenotyping platforms with NARS collaborators.
item.description: The first main objective of this activity is to identify the key stress adaptive traits, and combinations of traits, that will be needed to maintain productive wheat crops in warmer regions now and in the future climate scenarios. This will be achieved through analysis and modeling of detailed wheat trial data from heat stressed experimental environments. While conceptual models for adaptation to heat stress have already been developed by CIMMYT, simulation exercises using comprehensive data sets can help determine the levels of expression of traits required to maintain productivity across the range of stress profiles that are likely to be experienced in target sites, as identified by climate models. Clearly, for this information to be applied, experimental sites must be established where germplasm can be evaluated and selected for expression of the appropriate phenotype. Therefore, the second main objective is to develop phenotyping platforms with NARS collaborators so that they can breed for probable climates, e.g. 20 years into the future. While climate models can establish the broad meteorological parameters of future environments, the outputs from crop models will determine which aspects of growth will be most affected. This kind of information can help define the key characteristics of analogue sites since any given analogue site is only an approximation of a range of target environments. For example, it may be that reproductive growth becomes a new bottleneck to productivity, and therefore, it will be crucial that the stress profile at the analogue site around the crop stage of meiosis and anthesis closely matches those characteristics of the future climate scenario at the same growth stage. This is not only determined by air temperature but also relative humidity, radiation load, and water availability, since these factors also influence the expression of plant temperature.

item.title: Identify and evaluate differential role and impact of risk management strategies in maize-legume systems on women and men using farm household bioeconomic models.
item.description: This works aims to produce policy recommendations on livelihood-based gender-equitable risk management strategies aiming at reducing vulnerability to climate change in rural smale-scale maize households. Bioeconomic modelling will be used to select promising interventions that can be used by men and women farmers to enhance their livelihoods in the face of risks brought by climate change. This will inform the establishment of participatory demonstration field trials on climate risk management among vulnerable farming systems in East Africa.

item.title: Participatory experimentation with risk management strategies in maize-legume-based systems in EA.
item.description: This activity aims to generate an inventory and recommendations for agronomic strategies to increase productivity and climatic risk management in maize-legume based systems in the East and Southern Africa at the field and farm level. Several risk management practices and strategies have been developed and advocated but in different ecologies. However, their real impact at the farm level is variable. Local adaptation through the incorporation of farmer experiences in technology development is crucial for acceptance of the technology and also enhancing confidence levels of the farmers (risk reducing strategy ) for large scale adoption. Participatory experimentation holds the key to success of most technologies in general but in particular to CA-based management practices in order to reduce farmer risk and to increase farmer-to-farmer out-scaling.

item.title: Policy recommendations on approaches to manage market risks and create strategies to reduce vulnerability of poor households (producers and consumers) arising due to price volitality.
item.description: Agricultural sector, and in particular farmers, are highly vulnerable to risks due to high variability in climatic conditions and to market uncertainties. Farmer exposure to risk and uncertainty is often aggravated by lack of information about weather, inputs, farm management practices or market prices, and this lack of information has an adverse impact on crop production and income. Some of these risks, for example the risk of a bad monsoon, affect agriculture as a whole, while other risks vary from region to region, and the severity of their impact depends on an individual farmer knowledge and coping ability. The evidence suggests that a farmer who receives quality, up-to-date information, and who has the ability to use that information, is able to lessen the effect of these risks.

item.title: Analysis of the economic incentives and benefits to farmers from adoption of conservation agriculture for adaptation to and mitigating climate change.
item.description: This activity aims to identify and disseminate incentive systems and policy instruments for enhancing adoption of wheat-based climate smart agricultural practices. Adoption of conservation agriculture (CA) remains important for adapting to and mitigating climate change in IGP. However, adoption of CA, like other technologies, is affected by the economic benefits associated with it. Thus, a careful analysis of the economic incentives and benefits to farmers from adoption of CA is required.

item.title: Calculation of carbon footprints of maize in EA based on the SIMLESA datatset.
item.description: Through its bilateral projects, CIMMYT has conducted extensive large scale socio-economic and agronomic surveys of smallholder maize- and wheat-based cropping systems in Sub-Saharan Africa and Asia. The corresponding datasets of thousands of households across a wide range of agro- climatic zones represent a potentially rich source of input/output data from which greenhouse gas emissions and carbon footprints can be calculated. If sufficiently robust carbon footprints can be calculated at the crop, plot and household level using these datasets then this opens up all sorts of exciting opportunities to upscale from the crop to the regional and landscape levels for better targeting of mitigation measures and/or opportunities.

item.title: Potential of CA to mitigate GHG emissions in cereal-based systems in different agroecologies.

Different management practices in various production systems and ecologies may effect C sequestration. Documentation of C sequestration potential of various management practices and landscapes offers opportunities for prioritising investments in suitable technologies and policy development. However, data needs, analytical tools and techniques makes all the differences in the output and this warrants the development of systematic and harmonized protocols together with an analysis of exisiting datasets.

item.description: Climate change is a continuous phenomenon and it is difficult to quantify its future impacts. There is an urgent need for methods and tools that enable us to make a reasonable assessment of both the present and future impacts of climate change. It is, therefore, imperative to develop and test these tools. Dynamic crop models are now useful tools to create and analyse the impacts of different climate change scenarios and develop policy foresights.
