item.title: Socio-economic assessment of the needs and suitability of water storage options and technical feasibility assessment of storage in Nepal; Formulation of storage development guidelines in the context of basin development plan.
item.description: Nepal has significant water resources and hydropower potential, but virtually no storage, large or small, to exploit any of the two in the context of adaptation to current and future variability that is increasing due to changing climate. The country currently revises its Water Vision and Irrigation Policy. The outputs of this activity should support water storage planning and development. Other countries in the Region face somewhat similar issues; and the attempt may be made to initiate similar work in Sri Lanka, India or Pakistan.

item.title: Development and application of approaches and methods for improved efficiency and equity of water allocation in aquaculture-irrigation farming systems of Malawi, Zambia and Mozambique under uncertain climates
item.description: Small scale irrigation and/or aquaculture farming systems are common in southern Africa, and provide livelihoods for many people. This activity looks at how these systems may be made more efficient under changing climate, and what are the social and gender implications of changing water allocation and use pattern in them

item.title: Analysis of possible future water re-allocation options to agriculture due to increased water desalination capacity coupled with increased clean energy use - globally. Synthesis of bright spots' examples of successful adaptation to climate change through agricultural water management (AWM).
item.description: Possible impacts of new and emerging technologies on the pattern of water allocation to and use in agriculture need to be understood and projected. They may be an important factor in adaptation of agriculture to climate change - globally. Also, there are many examples of successful or promising ways of adaptation to climate change in agricultural water management sector in developing countries worldwide. This activity aims to collate and synthesize such examples.

item.title: Regional analysis Managed Aquifer Recharge and related interventions in CCAFS Climate Smart Villages as an option to offset climate change impacts and improve water availability and access for poor rural men and women.
item.description: With increasing temperatures in many parts of the world, evaporation from surface water bodies and storages increases too. Also, surface storage as a buffer of increasing water resources variability may become less effective with time. Finally, access to surface storages in rural areas is not always equitable. All the above put more attention to investigation of "underground" water solutions for adaptation. Managed (facilitated, enhanced) aquifer recharge (MAR) may be one of these. But it depends a lot on hydrogeology and water availability for recharge, acceptance of technologies, effectiveness, willingness of the Governments and Private sector to invest in those etc. This activity looks into the plethora of these issues regionally and in CCAFS sites, where various MAR interventions, including assessment of MAR potential, interventions to decrease groundwater pumping, minimization of duration of waterlogging through vertical drains, community managed village ponds, shallow subsurface drains etc.

item.title: Simulating impacts of possible climate change on irrigation management in selected schemes and in overall Indus basin. Modellng the impacts of climate change on availability of water for agriculture in the Nile and, Possibly - Niger basin
item.description: This activity involves water allocation modelling and analysis of implications for water availability to agriculture in some major irrigation schemes or basin under possible scenarios of future climates.

item.title: Analysis of patterns of vulnerability and adaptive capacity for women, with a focus on agricultural water management in Nepal, North India and Bangladesh. Literature review on the topic and field studies in three communities in watersheds in Nepal considered highly vulnerable to climate change.
item.description: This is an explicit, gender-focused research activity which aims to comprehensively assess gender aspects of adaptation to climate change through water and related interventions in South Asia.

item.title: Developing integrated science-stakeholder-policy approach to Adaptation in Water and Agriculture sectors in Andhra Pradesh, and Tamilnadu states of India. Analysis of production risk and farm technology adoption in climate change prone rainfed eco-systems of Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh and Tamilnadu
item.description: This activity aims to analyse possible risks from climate change to farming systems in Peninsular India, and to examine actual adoption of adaptation strategies by farmers in the region. On that basis, policy recommendations to relevant State Governments for targeted adaptation will be made.

item.title: Agricultural sector adaptation planning in Sri Lanka.
item.description: Agricultural sector adaptation planning in Sri Lanka. Outputs will be carefully inserted in the political context, through articulation of the plans and strategies within ongoing and upcoming national and sub-national policy initiatives. (Participatory approach combining biophysical sciences with socio-political studies)

item.title: Analysing risks from catastrophic floods in Asia, and current trends in catastrophic flooding due to changing climate - with impacts on production, livelihoods and food security - at sub-national scale in selected countries in South Asia and East Africa.
item.description: Information on flood-related risks and their recent changes, expressed in terms of frequency of flooding, population affected, Economic losses, crop area affected , etc. - is important for formulating flood protection measures and targeting associated investments. Such information is not available in Africa and Asia at the fine scale of spatial resolution, at which actual decisions have to be made.

item.title: Implementation of cell-phone based Pilot information services (condition of crops, soil, water) to selected farming communities in Egypt, Ethiopia and Sudan.
item.description: Provision of targeted new information services to farmers, on conditions of their individual fields and crops, irrigation scheduling, and anticipated water availability - alls based on modern satellite sensor data and mobile technology, is already a reality in many European countries and America. This activity explores the potential of rolling out such services in Africa.

item.title: Defining site-specific adaptation programs in major rice-growing areas with specific vulnerabilities in South and Southeast Asia.
item.description: The overarching objective of this activity is the identification of – and eventually profiting from – synergies between the envisaged adaptation in rice-based systems and other trends towards higher productivity and resource use efficiency, such as technology campaigns run by national agencies. The geographic focus remains on mega-deltas of S and SE Asia, in particular Mekong in Vietnam and Ganges-Brahmaputra in Bangladesh. Regions prone to heat stress are likewise studied for potential adaptation through adjusted cropping calendar. While technological breakthroughs in rice breeding and crop management may help farmers cope with these climate change impacts, it is not uncommon to find farmers who are either unaware of or reluctant to adopt changes in farming practices, e.g. alternate-wetting-and-drying (AWD). The IRRI-CCAFS activities in 2012 revealed the site-specific distinctions for defining adaptation strategies as local conditions largely vary in terms of hydrology and temperature regimes. Moreover, the differences (observable or otherwise) among household members in their perception of and vulnerability to climate change and socioeconomic shocks, i.e. gender-differentiated impact, demand gender-differentiated adaptation options in rice-based production systems. In the process, household risk management and intra-household resource allocation have to be re-evaluated and modified, if at all. An assessment of the various gender-specific adaptations as well as site-specific strategies should be made vis-à-vis national agriculture development programs to allow for potential synergies or detect inconsistencies that may give rise to risks or problems.

item.title: Development of climate smart ideotypes for breeding strategies in rice and sorghum.
item.description: This IRRI-CCAFS activity, which is under the supervision of Michael Dingkuhn, IRRI-CIRAD crop physiologist and modeler, will continue in 2013 with the systematic scenario simulations of rice adaptation and responses to current and anticipated variability of climate (down-scaled GCM scenarios). These will be done at the field and plant population scale, at different sites, including irrigated and rainfed environments in S and SE Asia, W Africa and possibly S America. The two crop models: (1) SAMARA (full crop model specifically developed to simulate trait interactions and GxE interactions on the phenotype) and (2) RIDEV (focused on phenology and thermal stresses) will be further developed with the involvement of the CCAFS-funded PhD scholar (A Kumar). In support of this CCAFS modeling work, IRRI has initiated collaboration with the Manila Observatory which has access to various GCM output databases as well as expertise in down-scaling methodologies to scales utilizable in crop modeling. The expected results will provide regional climate change scenarios of 3 target regions in India, Thailand and the Philippines to be used as inputs for crop models. Crop data collection from various regions and model improvement, calibration and validation are expected to be completed this year. Upon sensitivity analysis of yield to crucial adaptation traits, ideotypes will be formulated and proposed as a guidance to breeders.

item.title: Identifying region-specific options for improved resilience of rice production to cyclones/ typhoons in terms of varietal selection
item.description: The aggravating trends in frequency and intensity of cyclones/ typhoons in S and SE Asia necessitate the adjustment of rice farming systems such as selection of more resilient cultivars and more suitable crop calendars. The typhoon analysis in 2012 consisted of identifying the location-specific intensities and duration of typhoon events based on local weather records in combination with rainfall and wind speed classes. This will be taken as a basis for defining specific strategies in 2013.

item.title: Development of food system-level research and partnerships, including decision support tools for national and international food security and humanitarian response
item.description: Development and disaster response represent different parts of a continuum of variability, but involve distinct sets of institutions and policies. Building resilience to climate variability requires a partnership approach. When responding to climate shocks requires humanitarian action, timing is important, as delays can lead to long-term loss of livelihood potential and increased vulnerability. Integration of climate information into existing early warning systems and analytical process has potential to improve timeliness of intervention. Neglect of agricultural R&D eroded resilience and increased vulnerability. Recognizing the need to reduce vulnerability by increasing resilience, humanitarian organizations have expanded their involvement in agricultural development, but without building on the foundation of agricultural research (and sometimes without adequate coordination). There is both a need and opportunity to strengthen partnerships between the agricultural research and food security / humanitarian communities.

item.title: Promoting mitigation projects in rice-based production systems in South and Southeast Asia (planning phase).
item.description: The promotion of GHG mitigation projects in rice production – focussing on alternate-wetting-and-drying (AWD) – will continue this year with the planning phase leading to a wide-spread adoption within a 5-yr time frame. The AWD project will now include experiments that compare results of different GHG measurement approaches (manual chamber, automated chamber, eddy covariance). The assessment of AWD mitigation potential and water-saving feature will still be carried out in the rice-growing regions of Vietnam and the Philippines taking into account the distinction among irrigation systems. All these provide a good occasion to consolidate and test reliable MRV (Measurement, Reporting and Verification) guidelines. Moreover, the smoke collection set-up which was fabricated and set-up at IRRI is used to estimate emission rates from rice straw burning as a function of moisture content and this will facilitate the formulation of a CDM methodology for preventing such activities among farmers. Building on the known involvement of farming households in mitigation projects from preliminary interviews, this activity will further identify the scope for female engagement in changing crop management practices, e.g. controlled consumption of irrigation water. A closer look into the gender roles and relations within the household could provide some indications on how to convince each member on the virtues of water-saving techniques. A participatory approach will be employed to promote AWD, giving the farmers some degree of flexibility in terms of the timing and pacing of the suggested water saving technique. This approach will take their socioeconomic characteristics and the agro-climatic conditions of the irrigated service area into consideration.

item.title: Integrating validated simulation models into a decision support system on mitigation projects rice production systems.
item.description: The need to integrate validated simulation models into a decision support system on mitigation projects cannot be overemphasized. In order to achieve this goal, IRRI in collaboration with CCAFS has strived to establish networks with other institutes involved with modelling of climate change impacts on rice production. However, simulation models are inherently complex in terms of required input parameters and operation, so that their direct use as decision support tools is generally limited. Thus, we will work with simplified input-output tables that derived from modeling results and incorporated into Techinical Coefficient Generators. These tools will be further validated this year for more precise climate impact assessments and extreme climatic events, namely drought and salinity stress in S and SE Asia. Moreover, IRRI will continue its active participation in the Agricultural Model Intercomparison and Improvement Project (AgMIP).

item.title: CGIAR Center support to include climate change research in the "Global Futures for Agriculture" project.
item.description: The main activity of the Global Futures for Agriculture (GFA) project at the IRRI is the development of tools to improve evaluation of ex-ante returns to rice research, technology development, and adoption modeling. The GFA combines bio-physical (ORYZA2000 crop growth simulation model) and economic models (IRRI Global Rice Model) to assess the economic benefits of the development and dissemination of the virtual drought tolerant rice in various South Asian countries under the presence of climate change projected by Canadian Global Circulation Model. Using similar techniques, the project is keen to extend the ex-ante impact assessment of the dissemination of the same drought tolerant rice to Africa and Latin America and to rainfed rice areas of East Asia.

item.title: Community-based Insurance in Agriculture: Conceptualization and Institutionalization of the Processes.
item.description: Agricultural insurance is one of the most effective ways to reduce the risk and cope-up the climatic eventualities. In view of tiny land holdings owned by the Indian farmers, agricultural insurance is considered to be the most effective tool to minimize losses in the event of climatic variability. In India, Agricultural Insurance Corporation (AIC) is pioneer to launch various agricultural insurance products to reduce the risk arising due to various climatic variations. Over the years, a number of agricultural insurance products were developed and promoted by the AIC. In recent years, private sector and non-governmental organizations were also engaged in agricultural insurance sector. Despite of concerted efforts by the AIC and private sector, agriculture insurance is not as attractive and successful as it is in general and life insurance and health sector. Lack of awareness, absence of transparency, difficulty in getting claims are being cited key obstacles in larger acceptance of agricultural insurance by the famers. It is also envisaged that the transactions cost of the insurance company are high for large number of farmers with small amount of premiums and claims. To overcome such problems, community-based agricultural insurance can play an important role. In this context there are some successful models in different countries; their processes, structure and inclusiveness are to be understood for their adaptation in Indian context, specifically for smallholders. The study is an attempt in this direction.

item.title: Investigating the Impact of Climate Extremes on Future Water and Food Security.
item.description: Extreme hydroclimatic events such as droughts and floods cause huge damages in South Asia and East Africa, in particular to agricultural production and rural livelihoods. Long-term climate projections suggest that more frequent and severe hydroclimatic extremes are likely to happen in the future. Enhancing farmers’ coping capacity and improving agricultural and water policies will increase the resilience of rural community towards both today’s and future hydroclimatic extremes. This project aims to provide policy-relevant recommendations through conducting the following research activities: (1) quantitatively assess drought severity and frequency in the study regions using statistical and biophysical models to identify vulnerable areas and inform drought mitigation; (2) build a risk-based optimization (stochastic programming) model to prioritize mitigation measures; (3) analyze farmers’ perception of and responses to droughts in the past to identify adaptation gap; and (4) construct hydroclimatic extreme scenarios for the study regions, assess their macro impacts, and identify promising mitigation policies using a global agricultural economic model.

item.title: Assessing the impact of appropriate risk management financial packages on household’s asset portfolios in Bangladesh.
item.description: Index insurance is an innovative financial product that helps rural households manage large covariate shocks to agricultural income. Current research is increasingly showing that an effective risk management strategy in the face of climate change will require a combination of indexed insurance, savings and credit and that the correct combination of these three financial products will likely depend on the nature of climatic shocks and rural financial markets. If rural communities have access to such risk management tools they can increase the degree to which they are able to withstand climate risks. This in turn is likely to increase their investments in technologies in which the return is dependent on the climate. The ultimate effect of insurance on the resilience of rural households is thus an empirical question that is likely to vary depending on the situation being considered. In year 1 a structural model was designed to make predictions about the likely impact of index insurance and other financial instruments on a rural communities’ resilience to climate related risk. In 2013 predictions from the structural model will be used to inform the design of a treatment arm of a planned randomized control trial in Bangladesh in which insurance is offered to rural households. The treatment will be designed to test the predictions of the model about the type of risk insured by the insurance product (health versus agriculture, extreme versus moderate risk) and household outcomes. The validity of the model will be tested by comparing model predictions with results from the field.

item.title: Climate change adaptation, mitigation and building economic resilience in West Africa and South Asia.
item.description: In this study we look at two countries in the West Africa/ECOWAS region and India, and evaluate economic and agro-ecological vulnerabilities to climate variability and long-term climate change. We combine a micro-level analysis of farm-level adaptation response and impact analysis with a macro-level analysis of impact response and adaptation at an economy-wide level. We look at the implications of higher int'l prices for high imported food countries, as well as the decline in crop yields. The impact on the balance of payment and the related spillover effect within the economy are also considered, along with impacts on important agricultural sectors such as livestock.

item.title: Low Emission Development Strategies (LEDS) in agriculture.
item.description: It is now widely recognized that natural resource use in many developing countries, from crop production to deforestation, is responsible for the bulk of greenhouse gas emissions. We also know that in many countries, it is the agriculture and forestry sectors—not industry or transport—that provide low-cost mitigation opportunities. As countries experience economic growth and choose among the available development pathways, they are in a favourable position to adopt natural resource use technologies and production practices characterized by low GHG emissions. Rather than embedding high emissions practices in their development and intervene on emissions reduction at a later stage, they can utilize Low Emissions Development Strategies (LEDS).

item.title: Study on the economic viability of climate change mitigation through the use biochar.
item.description:
Work completed by IFPRI and collaborators in Ghana, indicates that while the potential for carbon sequestration through carbon accumulation in agricultural soils is a substantial reality, its quantification presents considerable challenges. In order to compute the amount of carbon sequestered, one has to create a baseline of soil carbon for a period of 15 – 20 years and this requires predicting farmers’ agricultural decisions for the same period. Soil organic carbon content is highly dependent on crop choices, input usage, and on agronomic practices implemented, and it is particularly difficult to predict smallholder farmers’ choices for long periods of time. In fact, poor farmers have a very short planning horizon and decisions about input usage and agronomic practices are dependent on market vagaries, family size, and other hard-to-predict factors. There is, though, one practice in the area of study that is recurrent, widespread, and very predictable: slash and burn. This practice is used to clear a plot of land after a few years of fallow. Slash and burn saves labor, kills pests, and returns a small amount of minerals to the soil. However, the transformation of woody fallow growth into biochar, which directly avoids CO2 emissions and could be used as a soil amendment, could be a viable alternative to current practices.
Biochar is charcoal produced from biomass using an anaerobic process called pyrolysis and its chemical characteristics make it particularly valuable. The form of carbon present in biochar is thought to be stable in the soil for hundreds of years. Furthermore, biochar can increase soil water- and nutrient-holding capacity with direct positive effects on yields, particularly in nutrient-deficient soils. The stability of the biochar carbon, the immediate reduction of CO2 emissions, and the positive effects on yields, substantially reduce problems related to permanence and MRV that limit the viability of other climate change mitigation methods in agriculture.

item.title: Capturing the potential for greenhouse gas offsets in Indian agriculture.
item.description: The Indian Government recently announced an aggressive GHG emissions intensity target of reducing emissions by 20-25 percent by 2020 on 2005 levels. Policy-makers now face the challenge of developing and implementing policy options consistent with this target. A critical challenge will be to find ways of exploiting low cost mitigation opportunities in sectors like agriculture, while also minimising the cost of emission reduction targets on India’s growing energy and industry sectors to not unduly curtail broader economy-wide growth prospects. An important issue addressed in this project concerns the extent to which broader policy reform in India’s agricultural sector might contribute to national emission reduction targets. Beyond these broader reforms, lie specific mitigation policies like ‘agricultural offsets’ which provide a mechanism by which sectors facing higher marginal abatement costs can tap low cost mitigation opportunities within agriculture. In some instances, realising mitigation opportunities within agriculture may also offer potential to further enhance existing Indian programs and policies aimed at increasing agricultural productivity and improving the sustainability of India’s farming systems. The approach could have beneficial international implications by clearly showing the central role that agriculture can play in GHG abatement in emerging and developed economies alike.

item.title: Global agricultural model intercomparisons with AR5 data (AgMIP project).
item.description: AgMIP is a distributed climate-scenario simulation exercise for historical model intercomparison and future climate change conditions with participation of multiple crop and agricultural economics modeling groups around the world. The goals of AgMIP are to improve substantially the characterization of risk of hunger and world food security due to climate change and to enhance adaptation capacity in both developing and developed countries. AgMIP will significantly enhance information (including uncertainty estimates) to guide policymakers regarding risk of hunger, world food security, and agricultural adaptation. A key aspect is to create capacity-building partnerships among agricultural crop and economic modelers around the world, enhancing the ability of each nation to evaluate current and future climate impacts and adaptations. As part of the above program, IFPRI is co-leading the Economics team. Under this activity, it aims to establish a methodological and procedural foundation for the systematic comparison and improvement of global and regional land use, production and trade models used for analysis of climate change impact, as well as mitigation and adaptation in the agricultural sector. It will involve coordinating and facilitating intercomparison of both regional and global agricultural market models being used for climate change impact and adaptation research. Achieving these objectives will include participating in the AgMIP cross-cutting themes to build collaborations between climate scientists, crop modelers and economic modeling groups to improve methods and procedures that allow crop model simulations to be used as inputs into economic models.

item.title: Increasing Women’s Resilience to Confront Climate Change.
item.description: There is some evidence to suggest that unequal access to and control over assets make women particularly vulnerable to the negative impacts of climate change both in terms of their sensitivity to climate shocks and their adaptive capacity. Men and women are also likely to have very different perceptions of climate change and climate risk, and very different approaches to adaptation. But there is very little data or analysis of gender differences in climate change impacts or ability to engage in climate-smart agriculture. Improved information on these issues is needed to design gender-sensitive and pro-poor climate change research approaches that will benefit women and men.

item.title: Quantification of regional scenarios using global integrated models.
item.description: Within the CCAFS programme, participatory scenarios are being developed and used for each region. The objectives of the scenarios activity are: 1. to capture key uncertainties for regional food security under conditions of global environmental and socio-economic change as seen from a range of societal perspectives; 2. to develop regional capacity for governance and decision-making in the face of uncertainty. In terms of these objectives, the development and use of the scenarios functions as a platform for the exchange and application of knowledge and experience between (CCAFS) researchers and policy makers, private sectors, NGOs and other societal actors. Under tis context, IFPRI and its IMPACT team, will work to quantify the qualitative scenarios developed in the CCAFS scenarios programme for South Asia, and Latin America using the IMPACT model in a participatory process, closely collaborating with the GLOBIOM team.

item.title: Development of modeling tools to handle aggregation, landuse, non-traded goods, and trade policies.
item.description: This is the continuation and conclusion of the related 2012 activity, that aimed on the release of a Verion III of the IMPACT model. The IMPACT model is designed to examine alternative futures for global food supply, demand, trade, prices, and food security. The IMPACT model allows to provide both fundamental, global baseline projections of agricultural commodity supply, demand, trade, prices and malnutrition outcomes along with cutting-edge research results. A new version of the IFPRI global, multimarket model, IMPACT has been developed, that so far has included a number of new features: (1) Capability of working with any country, region, and/or commodity aggregation of the IMPACT data base, (2) Incorporates non-traded commodities and commodities that can be non-traded if the equilibrium domestic price falls between the export and import prices, (3) Incorporates tariffs and export taxes/subsidies, in addition to producer and consumer subsidies, which are in the earlier versions of IMPACT, (4) Incorporates a new land use specification that extends the existing area equations in Impact to allow for efficient allocation of land across crops in each region (food production unit,FPU), separately modeling the supply and demand for land by type (rainfed and irrigated) and crop. These new features were first implemented in a simplified version,designed to provide researchers with a teaching version of the model that facilitates transfer of the Impact model to other institutions (e.g., CGIAR centers). Toward the end of 2012, work was started to transfer the new features to a new version of the full Impact model. This work is continuing in 2013, and the new IMPACT model, with all the new features, is scheduled to replace the earlier model in the second quarter of 2013.

item.title: CGIAR Center support to include climate change research in the "Global Futures for Agriculture" project.
item.description: The Global Futures project aims to assist the CGIAR in identifying priority research investments through the use of quantiative forecasting models that can account for climate change scenarios. ICRAFs particular involvement is twofold: first to analyze agroforestry options in terms of expected impacts and second to improve the existing ex ante modeling framework to better handle natural resource management technologies -- the current platform of DSSAT and IMPACT is much better suited to analyzing impacts of new crop varieties. Several activities are required to enable this to be done, among them is collection of high quality data sets that will enable the parameterization of the models. The CCAFS funds in 2013 are being used to collect data that can be used for this purpose.

item.title: Development of new virtual crop parameters for assessment of potential investments to improve resilience to climate change for potato and sweet potato.
item.description: Breeders are interested in applications of crop growth models to explore the performance of a particular clone or variety in different environments and to assess the performance of so called “virtual cultivars”. The experiences recorded in the present activity may add valuable information and can contribute to the ongoing communication between breeders and crop modelers at CIP about this issue.

item.title: Model application to assess the impacts of climate change in rangeland systems, including changes in biomass availability, plant functional groups, and carbon and nitrogen fluxes.
item.description: Temperate and tropical rangelands are the most extensive land type on earth. They are biologically diverse and support the livelihoods of millions of households. In most rangelands, there is not sufficient precipitation for agriculture, and so families use livestock to essentially turn sunlight into food. Historically, the inhabitants of these areas had to contend with droughts, fires, livestock raids, and other stressors and shocks. Animals evolved physical and behavioral adaptations such as high heat tolerance and migration, and people adopted behaviors such as transhumant movement and developed cultural norms that minimized exposure to stresses. Flexibility came to be a defining feature of pastoral communities, and their adaptive capacity was great. The 21st century will bring unprecedented climate change to semi-arid and arid systems (at least within human history). These stressors will reduce further the adaptive capacity of coupled semi-arid and arid systems. One means of increasing the likelihood that households, enterprises, and land managers will be able to adapt to future changes is if future conditions can be anticipated. A quantitative method of anticipating future conditions is through using simulations, where inputs into simulations are modified as predicted in change scenarios. We propose to develop and apply a new grazingland ecosystem model to better understand future changes in rangelands across the globe. The tool we have developed (Grange) is responsive to changes in precipitation and temperature through time, it is spatially explicit, and of moderate complexity (therefore high utility). We propose to continue to develop and test the model against a growing variety of observations and to carry out multi-scale analyses of native rangelands and the changes they may undergo.

item.title: Review of livestock - related migitation and adaptation strategies at regional level including assessments of their application domains and potential impacts on productivity and GHG emissions.
item.description: As countries put policies in place to curb GHG emissions, the livestock sector will be concerned. A variety of options have been identified for mitigation of greenhouse gas emissions from livestock production systems. In addition, the likelihood of further climate change occurring, and the increasing scale of potential climate impacts require adaptation of the livestock sector. The ANIMALCHANGE project has been designed to provide an integrated view of possible futures of the livestock sector under climate change and will deliver scientific guidance on options and policies for both mitigating GHG emissions from the sector and adapting to climate change. ANIMALCHANGE will analyse the mutual benefits of adaptation and mitigation scenarios for a wide range of livestock production systems. This activity contributes integrally to the ANIMALCHANGE project. It will explore adaptation issues and adaptation/mitigation interaction issues at a regional scale (landscape or farming system level). It aims to identify the most promising options for combined mitigation and adaptation in livestock systems at regional level.

item.title: Explore institutional arrangements to support adaptation at local level.
item.description: The role of local instittuions in constraining or fostering adapative capacity is well described in the scientific literature, but translating this into impact remains a challenge. This research will help CCAFS to understand the role of governance and instititutions in three benchmark sites, contributing to this milestone. The work will also help to identify indicators to use in assessing the impact of adpatation interventions.

item.title: IBLI product assessed and efforts to catalyze sales continue. IBLI surveys (assessment and herd collaring) continue in Borena, Ethiopia.
item.description: The activity emcompasses actions and objectives with sit within the broader project titled "Index-Based Livestock Insurance: Adapation and Innovations for Ethiopia". The project builds on lessons learned and ongoing activity from the pilot venture underway in northern Kenya, adapting that pilot and the product to the Ethiopian context. Having launched sales in southern Ethiopia in July of 2012, there are now over 550 active contracts after two sale windows. As part of the impact assessment effort, we have a rigorous impact evaluation design based on quasi-experimental techniques as well as GPS tracking of collared herds. We are also working to explicitly incorporate IPCC predictions and climate change and associated biomass dynamics to explore dynamic pricing. The particlar elements of this activity involve efforts to increase adoption and continued survey work as part of the impact assessments.

item.title: Household level modelling of risk management strategies in diverse farming systems in the CCAFS regions, including the development of improved models and up and outscaling approaches.
item.description: Household level modelling of risk management strategies in diverse farming systems in the CCAFS regions, including the development of improved models and up and outscaling approaches.

item.title: Studies on incentives for mitigation in rangeland systems and potential for carbon sequestration in rangelands.
item.description: The rationale of activites is first to analyse the changes in land cover and what are the drivers. In Eastern Africa population pressure and land tenure and land policy are driving changes in the way we managed land. Secondly, the assess the carbon stock in the various land management areas will give an insight if we are making positive or negtative contrubutions to GHGs. Lastly, we need to analyse how new institutional arrangements in land management can play a role in reducing GHGs but also improving the livelihoods and what are the additonal incentives for smallholder farmer or agro-pastoralist to invest in mitigating GHGs.

item.title: Studies on mitigation strategies in livestock systems.
item.description: Test of concept in field conditions: High-yielding animals producing more milk per lactation generally exhibit lower emissions. Emissions are spread over a greater volume of milk, thus diluting emissions relative to the maintenance requirements of the animal. The emissions associated with the extra inputs to increase milk yield is often much lower than the efficiency related emission reductions.

item.title: Coordinate development of low cost protocol ('SAMPLES') for quantification of key farming systems of East and West Africa, and SE Asia, in collaboration with ICRAF, IRRI and other centres.
item.description: GHG emission from smallholder farms are largely unknown, but of high significance for national GHG emissions in developing countries. This activity will develop low cost protocols for assessing GHG emissions at farm and landscape level and provide approaches how to link data with socioeconomic surveys and identify suitable region specific mitigation options.

item.title: Capacity building on methods for quantification of GHG to national stakeholders (researchers and technicians), collection of information for characterizing GHG emissions, and farming system characterization (e.g. crop performance, soils, livelihoods). Establish on-farm experiments to measure GHG emissions, productivity, profitability and social acceptability through farmers interviews in three CCAFS sites.
item.description: Expanding knowledge on strategies for assessing GHG emissions at landscape scales including targeting, on-site and laboratory measurements of GHG, household surveys for assessing livelihood, synthesis of results and identification of region specific, feasible mitigation strategies. This will be done by on-site and centralized training activities involving regional researchers, scientists and technicians coming from Tanzania, Uganda, and Kenya.

item.title: Lead cross-CGIAR team on development of a low-cost protocol for all GHG quantification at whole farm and landscape scales, appropriate for developing countries.
item.description: This is included in the larger SAMPLES project above (Activity 598)

item.title: Further analysis of how vulnerability to Rift Valley Fever (RVF) could change under different socio-economic scenarios and how to include this information in decision support.
item.description: Climate change will affect and impact human health, which is a major concern for the global community. Much health-related research has focused on the future distribution and spread of infectious diseases, and in particular the negative health impacts of changes in transmission and outbreaks of vector-borne diseases (VBDs) as a result of climate change. The impacts may be direct, in terms of outbreaks of disease among human populations, or indirect, in the form of outbreaks of diseases that affect domesticated animals or plants, and therefore jeopardise food security, agriculture-based economic activities and trade. The effects will however be felt most acutely among the poorest and most vulnerable members of society. This activity focuses one of the high-impact diseases, Rift Valley Fever (RVF), in eastern Africa. It will incorporate climate trends, future disease risk with changes in socio-economic conditions to come up with vulnerability maps and thereby contribute to decision support and preparedness to future outbreaks.

item.title: Household modelling of adaptation and mitigation strategies in CCAFS benchmark sites.
item.description: The CCAFS benchmark sites cover a large range of different agro-ecological and socio-economic conditions. Last year a large effort was made t collect household level information from each of the CCAFS regions. This data will be analysed in 2013 and it will be used to parameterise and apply simple household models for testing the impacts of adapatation and mitigation strategies on different dimensions of human/farming systems well-being. item.title: Development of tools and data sets for assessing water-livestock climate change linkages and implications for sustainable livestock production alternatives.
item.description:
Classic climate change research presents what future climate scenarios will look like, driven by current and projected greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs). The policy community at the same time strive to limit climate change by setting global average temperature targets. Considering the fact that a global average temperature change will have very diverse regional and local impacts, it is interesting and important to investigate how a set target translates to local impacts. The first component will address this issue in a twofold way: I) By developing a multi-model assessment based CC data set to explore the risk of local climate change, i.e. the spread in temperature, precipitation and radiation. To be used as input to any “impact model”. II) By using the data set to see how a set temperature target locally impact blue water resource availability.
Agriculture, in particular livestock, is often highlighted as a major contributor of GHG emissions, linked to e.g. NOx emissions from feed cultivation, methane from ruminants, NH4 from manure, and carbon emission from land use change. However, the emissions are quite different from different systems and under different management. The rising demand for animal-source foods calls for environmentally secured “sustainable intensification” strategies. Evidence discriminating the magnitude of emissions from different production systems will enable informed decisions. The second component will address this issue in a twofold way: I) By developing a comprehensive “food system model” to assess GHGs emission trade-offs in the global livestock sector, using a system approach. II) By including GHGs as one dimension in development of multi-currency environmental assessment framework for smallholder dairy production in East Africa.

item.title: Seeds for Needs East Africa.
item.description: The diversity of genetic traits of crops represents our most important resource for adapting agriculture to 21st century climate change. Ethiopia is a country rich in agricultural biodiversity and it is considered a major centre of crop domestication in Africa. The high diversity within cultivated crops can be used to adapt local farmers’ systems to climate change. An important means for small-scale farmers to adapt to climate change is by shifting their crop varieties to those better suited to future environmental conditions. Changing varieties is the main adaptation strategy to temperature alterations, and the single most important strategy, after soil conservation, to changes in precipitation patterns. However, roughly half of the farmers surveyed were unable to use different crop varieties, due to the lack of available information. The activity aims to improve farmers’ access to information and seed material from adapted varieties, which should considerably improve their ability to sustain food production in the face of climate change through the increased use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture. In addition, this activity aims at gaining an overview of the context in which the project is operating and understand local production systems and crop productivity trends, challenges and opportunities. It sought to probe local farmers’ knowledge of climate change and its impacts, to understand the farmers’ seed systems and any extant access barriers to seed, and to capture farmers’ crop variety preferences. This information is crucial for delivering a successful intervention.

item.title: Seeds for Needs China.

item.title: Seeds for Needs PNG.
item.description: This project is taking place in Papua New Guinea (PNG) and aims to identify conserved sweet potato and taro varieties that are adapted to climate change conditions, in addition to helping local communities’ farming systems adapt to environmental stresses caused by climate change. item.title: Seeds for Needs Laos Cambodia.
item.description: In the face of predicted changes in climate, the seeds accessed through this activity will help ensure the continued production of these staple foods to feed an expanding population. The activity will enable communities in Laos and Cambodia to adapt food production to changes in climate and with a potential to impact upon some 10,000 smallholder farmers, ensuring they do not fall into deeper poverty. More specifically, by working with partners in Laos and Cambodia, local communities and women’s groups, this activity will help identify crop varieties that are hardy and able to grow in tough conditions as well as those valued the most by farmers, matching them with the areas where they will be most needed. GIS technology, environmental data, and scientists will be used to test and identify the most climate ready seeds. Indigenous farming communities will be equal partners, and will be supported to use and share traditional knowledge. Local seed systems will be examined and strengthened by building on the traditional knowledge of the farmers and current methods for exchanging seeds, ensuring the widest access to seeds held in genebanks and on others farmers’ fields.

item.description: The scope of this Activity is to assess the role that indigenous knowledge plays in enhancing the use of local agrobiodiversity for greater adaptation of local production systems to climate change. The study will be carried out based on data gathered by two projects implemented in South/ East Asia and Latin America and will help answering a number of important questions regarding to role of local crops (NUS in particular) in adaptation and resilience such as 1) Which are the most resilient crops and what is the knowledge held by communities on their use? 2) What are those traditional practices that make use of NUS for enhancing adaptation/resilience? 3) How is knowledge being held and shared within the community and what are the threats and impediments to its conservation and valorization? 4) How does knowledge differ across men and women and how gender-related perceptions/actions complement one another? The analysis will also try to understand 5) How different socio-cultural-economic settings influence the way knowledge relevant to climate change and biodiversity is perceived, appreciated and promoted by people.

item.description: In this activity, we try to find out how informal seed systems can be harnessed and interfaced with formal systems in order to give farmers adequate access to crop varietal diversity in order to adapt to climate change and to deal with climate risk. We investigate a number of informal seed systems in CCAFS regions in Latin America, using quick diagnostic methodologies (linked to the local vulnerability assessments). Also, we investigate citizen science / crowdsourcing methods to involve farmers massively in variety evaluation in order to increase the varietal diversity for climate risk management and speed up the adaptation process. We pilot this approach for the first time in Latin America and train seed enterprises in this approach.

item.title: Climate change impact study of bananas and plantains, coconut and cacao.
item.description: Commodity crops like banana, cocoa and coconut offer challenges to climate change projection tools designed primarily for annual crops. Building robust climate change adaptation plans for these crops calls for parallel approaches – adapting and improving climate change modeling tools to the specific growth characteristics of semi-perennial and perennial crops and their pests and diseases, assessing and building appropriate partnerships for down scaling the focus of adaptation planning, compiling current crop management technologies to address variability and extreme events as a basis for addressing similar issues under climate change scenarios and carrying out climate change partners under a format of research for innovation. The commodity genetic resource networks and regional banana networks are proposed as appropriate partners for this work with diverse advanced research institutes. The activities in 2013 build on the review of existing tools and the initial development of new tools in 2011-12. With improved maps of banana which are being completed, modifications to Ecocrop suited to the growth characteristics and a framework for planning based on ecological response hierarchies and stakeholder capacities, we are moving toward more concrete planning tools. These will be piloted in 2013 with banana country partners in Latin America and East and West Africa.

item.title: Development of a regional strategic action plan for PGRFA management for climate change adaptation in Mesoamerica.
item.description: According to climate projections for the coming decades, Mesoamerica is one of the regions in Latin America expected to be most severely affected by climate change. Besides increases in temperatures, rainfall is expected to decrease significantly during the 21st century with longer and more pronounced droughts. Mesoamerica is also one of the world´s diversity hotspots and a centre of crop diversity. Several major globally important crops (e.g. maize, beans) were domesticated in this region, and a great variety of landraces of these are still cultivated in farmers’ fields. For other important crops, such as cassava, Mesoamerica is a secondary center of diversity. Research increasingly indicates that plant genetic diversity is the single most important resource in adapting crops to rapidly changing agro-ecological conditions and changing pest and disease patterns. Plant genetic resources for food and agriculture (henceforth PGRFA) are crucial for food security and health. However, there is still a lack of understanding about the potential to adapt to these changes precisely through the conservation, use and exchange of PGRFA. In the regional Mesoamerican context we are here addressing, all this has limited the contribution of PGRFA to the food security and sustainable development of the region and has resulted in limited capacity to formulate multisectorial policies which incorporate PGRFA in effective adaptive pathways against climate change. In order to fully take advantage of PGRFA’s potential for responding to food security and climate change challenges in the general context of environmental sustainability, the present proposal puts forward the development of a participatory, science-based, regional Strategic Action Plan (hereafter SAP) for the enhanced conservation, research and use of PGRFA in the Mesoamerican region.

This activity will seek seed funding to further develop and submit a collaborative cross-center, multi-CRP proposal to address this issue, and specifically the objectives below, including a baseline evaluation of climate change impact in Central America for CCAFS. item.title: Local climate change vulnerability assessment and adaptation planning.
item.description: Many climate adaptation decisions are taken at a local level. item.title: International Scoping Study of the Role of Agrobiodiversity as an Instrument for Climate Change Adaptation.
item.description:
There is a need to understand what policies can efficiently and equitably enhance farmers’ livelihoods by increasing their capacity to adapt to climate change. Climate change is expected to increasingly threaten the conservation of wild and domesticated biodiversity, including, agrobiodiversity, as changing local climates place habitats and species at increasing risk of extinction. Agrobiodiversity and associated ecosystem services are key factors that affect the resilience of agroecosystems and food security. However, the largest investments in food production continue to be associated with agricultural innovations to increase the productivity of some major crops and livestock, which are often advocated as crucial for agricultural climate change adaptation. Much less emphasis is being put on local systems that rely on existing natural, human and social capital assets such as agrobiodiversity, traditional knowledge and collective action institutions, such as seed systems, to reduce vulnerability and ensure food security.
A synthesis and assessment of the existing evidence for agrobiodiversity conservation and sustainable use as an instrument for climate change adaptation is needed. Together with the identification of research gaps, including with regard to the role of gender in agrobiodiversity conservation and use, as well as the developing and testing of interventions and incentive mechanisms, the project aims at demonstrating the value of agrobiodiversity and associated ecosystem services for human wellbeing especially in risky and rapidly changing agroecosystems.

Global Livestock Production Systems (GLPS) is an important layer that is used to stratify many analyses - mapping poor livestock keepers, estimating GHG emmissions, disease risk and impact mapping, to mention a few. This activitiy will revise the GPLS maps to incorporate new hybrid agricultural coverage daata (from the geo-wilki) and put this up on the Livestock-Geo-Wiki, along with global cattle, sheep and goats datat. Existing data will be used to produced a projected version of the GLPS to 2030, based on future estimates of length of growing period.

item.title: Mapping Risks and Opportunities for Targeting Appropriate Crop Adaptation Strategies in East Africa.
item.description:
Climate change will alter the distribution and intensity of the biotic and abiotic stresses that affect farming systems in East Africa (EA). Erratic rainfall patterns, temperature fluctuation, soil erosion, degrading soil quality, sensitivity to diseases and variation in biodiversity are examples of current climate change manifestations which will affect important livelihoods systems and food production. The implication of climate change is especially important in East Africa where the majority of the population is composed of rural poor dependent on small-scale farming as a source of food and income. Major food crops such as maize and legumes are highly vulnerable to climate variability implying the urgent need for adaptation strategies to extreme environments of heat, drought and excessive rainfall in some cases.
The overall aim of this activity is to assess the risks, opportunities and coping strategies related to agriculture and climate change in eastern Africa and this information together with local surveys will feed into additional activities planned for 2014 which aim to assess a range of promising interventions that could enhance food security under climate change. Some of these promising interventions are being tested in Uganda this year; they mainly relate to bean technologies. Others will be tested in Kenya in 2014; they mainly consist of improved maize technologies such as drought-tolerant maize, water-efficient maize and post-harvest storage technologies.
